text: there are a number of things that could
address this problem I think the primary
one
is the role of so-called Primary Care as
the Frontline for Health Care delivery
uh really needs to be
reinvented there are several
opportunities to innovate around what a
so called primary care physician does
and unfortunately since the current
model rewards Physicians for actually
doing things uh such as procedures as
opposed to thinking about things and
coordinating things we don't really have
a Workforce that is engaged in thinking
innovatively about primary care and
Primary Care delivery so if you are able
to start thinking about paying for
efficiency paying for so-called
performance paying for coordination of
care and paying
for a person who acts as the pinpoint
for the patient paying in a way for that
relationship between that primary care
provider and the patient then you would
have a way to build some efficiencies
into the
system I think patient Centric Care is
really the ethos of
primary care we as general internists
pediatricians family doctors are really
interested in doing what's best for the
patient and I think that can become uh
rather difficult given the pressures put
Upon Us by the folks who actually pay
for the care because sometimes they
might be more interested in what is the
actual cost of providing care for a
population so there are two
counterintuitive forces uh at hand here
you want the best care for your patient
who's sitting in front of you who might
be a diabetic but then you also want the
best care for the population of
diabetics within a
practice primary care doctors don't
really have the tools to provide both
and what we end up doing is providing
patient Centric
Care but not in the way that we would
like to do it simply because we don't
have the time to really sit and talk
with patients and think about informed
decisions we want patients to have the
information and then be able to make
shared decisions with the primary care
doctor as the person who's sharing that
decision with the patient so that would
really be what patient Centric Care is
about unfortunately in today's
environment we don't typically have time
to practice it right now again we're
paid for what we do which is actually
perers incentive so it makes us do more
and that's one of the reasons I think
you're seeing the cost of healthc care
rise 8% uh in terms of inflation per
year now that obviously can continue and
Obama has some uh proposals on the table
to reduce that increase by 1.5% per year
over the next few years I think
however if you start to pay for
performance pay for quality pay for
efficiency then you eliminate these
types of incentives so if a patient has
diabetes and can self-manage their blood
sugars which a lot of patients do uh but
now we have a tool which enables The
Physician or the care provider to
actually see those self-managed values
and work off of those to help coach the
patient as to how better manage their
blood sugars and behavior then it
doesn't matter where that management is
taking place so if that management is
taking place at the home but the outcome
in terms of quality is good or better
than the visit based model uh then you
have incentives to provide this type of
care so there are certain systems that
are in the United States right now that
seem to be able to provide better value
based care these systems that are
commonly mentioned or Kaiser or a Mayo
Clinic or a Ginger and what they do is
that they
have the ability to provide care across
the
Continuum so if you see someone within
the system you're likely to be referred
to somebody else within the system and
that information that you've that you is
obtained from the first person you saw
is seen by that second person so you
reduce the cost of
repetition
additionally
uh those systems tend to control their
administrative costs uh a lot tighter
and they also tend to follow certain
things like uh formulary restrictions
and they have decision support for their
physics uh in the electronic medical
records that they use and they all have
basically 100% electronic medical record
utilization electronic medical records
are important because they allow for
information
sharing the problem with electronic
medical records is that if there are a
hundred different vendors and therefore
100 different records that information
cannot be shared across so-called
systems so if you as provider X has a
certain system and me as provider y has
a different system uh those in those
systems don't share information in the
current state and as a result the goal
of the record in terms of making
information portable and
transferable is lost uh they're very
effective within the system so the tests
aren't repeated you can see tests that
were done the previous day or the
previous month they're very good for
trending tests and trending
information uh but the
real promise of the electronic
electronic medical record uh is not
obtained until you have a way to link uh
different records uh with different
Information Systems so if you would
think of the electronic medical record
as the car so you right now the
administration is buying cars but need
to build roads so that the cars can
travel and all that information that is
obtained at a practice in Denver can be
seen at a practice in Boston if a

uh the promise of the record starts to

can also provide a way for the patient
to have some input and and access to
information about their care if the
record not not only becomes the EMR the
the electronic medical record but uh
becomes a window to the personal health
record I believe that they should be one
in the same that the physician should be
able to see a part of a patient's record
and that the patient should have access
to the same information in a view that
he or she can
understand that would allow uh the
promise of the record uh to really be
realized because once you start giving
patients access to of their information
you start empowering patients you start
empowering
self-management and you start really
developing a shared strategy of care
between the patient and the care
provider I think that the government
should also think about investing in
things that enable patients to take
better care of themselves so again the
medical record is not enough we need
something that patients can see and we
need them to have access to their
information whether it's through readily
available technology like a cell phone
or a laptop or a pass key that they can

information yes there is a question of

types of things that that the government
should be uh spending their money on
from a technological perspective very
simple solutions that people could
understand and embrace uh as opposed to
again whizbang things that that people
typically are not going to use it's not
the technology that makes the difference
it's the implementation scheme and the
people behind the technology that
matter I think that we can use available
Technologies to really transform how we
deliver care so for example cell phone
platforms are available for patients to
manage their diabetes to manage blood
pressure we can take examples EX for
example from from subsaharan Africa
where patients with malaria instead of
coming back to the clinic after they've
had the test to see whether they have
malaria or not they receive an SMS to
say yes you have it and start this
medication or no you don't you don't
need to do anything else so there is an
available technology readily available
we have people the cell phone
penetration is uh extremely uh intense
throughout the United States why not use
that platform as a way to deliver care
and I think if we start thinking
differently about technology it's not
whizbang it's what we use every day and
implementing that into how we care for
folks uh that's where we can start to
create value and add efficiency into the
system when I finished
residency I remember trying to innovate
around how I took care of my high blood
pressure patients so I started to email
back and forth with the high blood
pressure patients to titrate their
medications and to prevent them from
coming in to have a visit with
me I thought that that would be slightly
uh more convenient for them and really I
didn't think it was a good use of my
time to sit and talk about blood
pressure when I could be handling it
over a very simple media such as
email unfortunately the payment system
uh didn't acknowledge that as a visit
and my practice administrators said said
you can't do that and I started to think
well that doesn't really make sense for
a system if I can't practice in a way
that makes sense for the patient in a
way that makes sense for me and keeps
the patient happy and actually provides

what am I doing in any
culture whether you have a shaman or a

the relationship between the person
delivering and providing the care and
the
patient uh we seem to think that
technology does have
some potential a lot of potential but

answer it's it's like how we use email
to share stories together um I don't
share stories with people I don't know
and usually stories that come to me from
people I don't know are spam so if I'm
going to be using available technology
to to manage patients um it has to come
from a trusted source and it should be
based in some
relationship so the work that I'm doing
for example is really housed in that

phys and the patient but using the

relationship uh again for example I have
uh a patient who is depressed and I send
him home on a

interacting with a machine when rating
their depression as opposed to uh
interacting with a person that's not to

so imagine if we enabled patients with

care delivery stream
